   Assessment and Plan
   52-year-old female with ALL s/p chemo and single cord blood
   transplantation complicated by CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia,
   VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis who presents with
   pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure:
   Respiratory status tenous overnight, on 100% FiO2 with sedation very
   high on fentanyl and midazolam; nursing able to cut both in half later
   in morning.  Pt seems to be saturating better on slightly increased
   tidal volumes.  Seemed to do worse overnight with PEEP increased.  On
   volume control w PEEP 15 currently w Vt 320cc.  Still mildly
   descynchronous w vent.  Has had a couple of trials of pressure control
   in past few days which she did not tolerate.  Was placed briefly on
   APRV last night as well, during which time she desatted.  BP did not
   tolerate propofol.
   - continue lasix gtt to get more fluid off w acetazolamide
   - follow up repeat chest x-ray from this AM
   - continue on Volume Control ventilation w current fentanyl and
   midazolam if tolerated, may benefit from valium and methadone to help
   decrease her overall levels of sedation
   - consider tapping pleural effusions though would be high risk
   procedure, not indicated at this time
   - consider getting fluid off faster with HD, though she is not in renal
   failure and has no other indication for HD
   - will tolerate paO2s in low 60s to be able to titrate down FiO2
   further
   .
   # Sepsis / Fever:
   Pt has had new fevers in last 36 hours.  Has been off pressors for an
   extended period of time, currently trending toward hypertension when
   sedation is weaned.  Sepsis initially due to multifocal PNA, as seen on
   CT chest. Wide differential given immunosuppression but Influenza and
   other respiratory virus panel negative; AFB smear on BAL was negative,
   urine legionella negative.  Culture from BAL with less than 1,000
   colonies, Gram stain negative for PMN
s or organisms. BAL: prelim
   negative for CMV.  New fever concerning for either a worsening
   pulmonary process or a new source of infection.   C diff [**11-17**]
   negative.  First glucan and galactomannan negative.
   - Micafungin added [**11-17**]
   - Empiric broad antibacterial coverage with vanc/meropenum, day 9 of 14
   (day 1 = [**11-10**])
   - F/U CMV VL, EBV PCR, repeat glucan, repeat galactomannan
   .
   # Anemia:
   Large Hct drop, didn
t get any fluids.  Did have elevated PTT 122 this
   AM, possibly from subq heparin; may have been bleeding somewhere
   lungs vs abdomen/GI. BUN not significantly elevated from yesterday.
   Subq heparin held for now
   - consider restarting subq heparin as [**Hospital1 7**] or half dose (2500 units)
   - repeat Hct
   - guaiac stools
   - Active T/S
   - Transfuse for Hct < 21
   .
   # Hypernatremia:
   Called pharmacy to switch antibiotics back to D5 fluid rather than NS.
   - Give free water flushes w tube feeds.
   - cont to monitor
   .
   # ARF: patient
s Cr stable at 0.9.  Initial hit secondary to ATN, but
   creatinine back to baseline.
   - will continue to adjust medication dosages based on improving CrCl,
   particularly the vanc and meropenem
   - continue lasix drip to decrease LOS fluid balance, goal of UOP
   greater than 150cc per hour (b/c getting at least 100cc/hr IN)
   .
   # Elevated LFTs: Currently stable
   - If they continue to rise will get a RUQ ultrasound Monday
   - Hold bactrim for now as concern for LFTs per BMT
   .
   # Non-Gap Acidosis:
   Acidosis Resolved.
   Bicarb climbing with diuresis, acetazolamide started yesterday to help
   keep bicarb from rising and blunting respiratory drive
   .
   # ALL:
   On chronic immunosuppression s/p single cord blood transplantation.
   - Cont acyclovir ppx
   - Will not need to restart tacrolimus
   - [**Month (only) 51**] need to increase Stress dose steroids, per BMT
 will increase
   back up to 100mg hydrocort IV or switch to solumedrol
   - will convert to prednisone when her intestinal motility improves and
   her acute process resolves (home dose is 5 mg daily)
   - Appreciate BMT recs
   .
   # Hep B:
   - Cont lamivudine
   .
   #Constipation:
   Need to continue bowel regimen aggressively b/c of increased fentanyl w
   sedation now.
   - continue po narcan prn and standing docusate b/c still on fentanyl
   - lactulose, bisacodyl, senna, erythromycin PRN also

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 52-year-old female with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who underwent single cord blood transplantation complicated by CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis. She presents with pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: She is intubated and ventilated on 100% FiO2 with sedation on fentanyl and midazolam. She has been having difficulty oxygenating and has required increased tidal volumes and PEEP.
* Sepsis/Fever: She has had new fevers in the past 36 hours, and her sepsis was initially due to multifocal PNA. She has been empirically treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics, and her CMV VL and EBV PCR are pending.
* Anemia: She has had a large Hct drop, and her PTT is elevated, possibly due to subcutaneous heparin. She is being monitored for bleeding and may require transfusion.
* Hypernatremia: Her sodium levels are elevated, and she is receiving free water flushes with tube feeds to correct this.
* Acute Renal Failure (ARF): Her Cr is stable at 0.9, and she is being monitored for any signs of worsening renal function.
* Elevated Liver Function Tests (LFTs): Her LFTs are elevated, and she is being monitored for any signs of worsening liver function.
* Non-gap Acidosis: Her acidosis has resolved, and she is being monitored for any signs of worsening acidosis.

The patient's medications include:

* Fentanyl (Concentrate) 400 mcg/hour
* Midazolam (Versed) 10 mg/hour
* Lasix (Furosemide) 20 mg/hour
* Heparin Sodium (Prophylaxis) 5,000 units subcutaneously every 12 hours
* Acyclovir (Zovirax) 1,000 mg every 8 hours
* Lamivudine (Epivir) 150 mg every 12 hours
* Erythromycin (Ery-Tab) 500 mg every 6 hours
* Pantoprazole (Protonix) 40 mg every 12 hours
* Haloperidol (Haldol) 5 mg every 12 hours
* Solumedrol (Methylprednisolone) 100 mg IV every 8 hours
* Micafungin (Mycamine) 50 mg every 24 hours

The patient's plan includes:

* Continue lasix drip to decrease fluid balance and increase urine output
* Continue empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics for sepsis
* Monitor for bleeding and transfuse if necessary
* Monitor for worsening renal function and adjust medications accordingly
* Monitor for worsening liver function and adjust medications accordingly
* Continue stress dose steroids and adjust as necessary
* Continue bowel regimen aggressively to manage constipation
* Continue to monitor for hypernatremia and acidosis.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: Prolonged intubation and ventilator dependence
* Sepsis/Fever: Worsening sepsis, multi-organ failure, and death
* Anemia: Bleeding, transfusion requirements, and worsening anemia
* Hypernatremia: Dehydration, electrolyte imbalance, and worsening acidosis
* Acute Renal Failure: Worsening renal function, electrolyte imbalance, and death
* Elevated Liver Function Tests: Worsening liver function, liver failure, and death
* Non-gap Acidosis: Worsening acidosis, electrolyte imbalance, and death.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management of her multiple medical conditions.

Summary:

The patient is a 52-year-old female with acute myeloid leukemia (ALL) who has undergone single cord blood transplantation and is currently in the ICU due to pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure. She has a complex medical history, including CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis. Her current conditions include hypoxemic respiratory failure, airway compromise, sepsis/fever, anemia, hypernatremia, acute kidney injury (ARF), elevated liver function tests (LFTs), and non-gap acidosis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is still tenuous, and she requires high doses of sedation to manage her ventilation. She has a high risk of developing ARDS, volume overload, and worsening infection.
2. Sepsis/fever: The patient's temperature has been elevated, and she has a wide differential diagnosis, including multifocal PNA, influenza, and other respiratory viruses. She has a high risk of developing a new source of infection.
3. Anemia: The patient's Hct has dropped significantly, and she has not received any fluids. She may be bleeding internally, and her PTT is elevated.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium levels are elevated, and she requires careful management to avoid further complications.
5. ARF: The patient's creatinine levels are stable, but she has a high risk of developing chronic kidney disease.
6. Elevated LFTs: The patient's liver function tests are elevated, and she may require further evaluation and management.
7. Non-gap acidosis: The patient's acidosis has resolved, but she may still require management to prevent further complications.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's current condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management. She requires ongoing respiratory support, sedation, and antibiotic therapy. Her anemia and hypernatremia require careful management, and she may require transfusions and fluid management. Her ARF and elevated LFTs require ongoing evaluation and management. Her non-gap acidosis has resolved, but she may still require management to prevent further complications. The patient's code status is full code, and her disposition is ICU.

   Assessment and Plan
   52-year-old female with ALL s/p chemo and single cord blood
   transplantation complicated by CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia,
   VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis who presents with
   pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure:
   Respiratory status tenous overnight, on 100% FiO2 with sedation very
   high on fentanyl and midazolam; nursing able to cut both in half later
   in morning.  Pt seems to be saturating better on slightly increased
   tidal volumes.  Seemed to do worse overnight with PEEP increased.  On
   volume control w PEEP 15 currently w Vt 320cc.  Still mildly
   descynchronous w vent.  Has had a couple of trials of pressure control
   in past few days which she did not tolerate.  Was placed briefly on
   APRV last night as well, during which time she desatted.  BP did not
   tolerate propofol.
   - continue lasix gtt to get more fluid off w acetazolamide
   - follow up repeat chest x-ray from this AM
   - continue on Volume Control ventilation w current fentanyl and
   midazolam if tolerated, may benefit from valium and methadone to help
   decrease her overall levels of sedation
   - consider tapping pleural effusions though would be high risk
   procedure, not indicated at this time
   - consider getting fluid off faster with HD, though she is not in renal
   failure and has no other indication for HD
   - will tolerate paO2s in low 60s to be able to titrate down FiO2
   further
   .
   # Sepsis / Fever:
   Pt has had new fevers in last 36 hours.  Has been off pressors for an
   extended period of time, currently trending toward hypertension when
   sedation is weaned.  Sepsis initially due to multifocal PNA, as seen on
   CT chest. Wide differential given immunosuppression but Influenza and
   other respiratory virus panel negative; AFB smear on BAL was negative,
   urine legionella negative.  Culture from BAL with less than 1,000
   colonies, Gram stain negative for PMN
s or organisms. BAL: prelim
   negative for CMV.  New fever concerning for either a worsening
   pulmonary process or a new source of infection.   C diff [**11-17**]
   negative.  First glucan and galactomannan negative.
   - Micafungin added [**11-17**]
   - Empiric broad antibacterial coverage with vanc/meropenum, day 9 of 14
   (day 1 = [**11-10**])
   - F/U CMV VL, EBV PCR, repeat glucan, repeat galactomannan
   .
   # Anemia:
   Large Hct drop, didn
t get any fluids.  Did have elevated PTT 122 this
   AM, possibly from subq heparin; may have been bleeding somewhere
   lungs vs abdomen/GI. BUN not significantly elevated from yesterday.
   Subq heparin held for now
   - consider restarting subq heparin as [**Hospital1 7**] or half dose (2500 units)
   - repeat Hct
   - guaiac stools
   - Active T/S
   - Transfuse for Hct < 21
   .
   # Hypernatremia:
   Called pharmacy to switch antibiotics back to D5 fluid rather than NS.
   - Give free water flushes w tube feeds.
   - cont to monitor
   .
   # ARF: patient
s Cr stable at 0.9.  Initial hit secondary to ATN, but
   creatinine back to baseline.
   - will continue to adjust medication dosages based on improving CrCl,
   particularly the vanc and meropenem
   - continue lasix drip to decrease LOS fluid balance, goal of UOP
   greater than 150cc per hour (b/c getting at least 100cc/hr IN)
   .
   # Elevated LFTs: Currently stable
   - If they continue to rise will get a RUQ ultrasound Monday
   - Hold bactrim for now as concern for LFTs per BMT
   .
   # Non-Gap Acidosis:
   Acidosis Resolved.
   Bicarb climbing with diuresis, acetazolamide started yesterday to help
   keep bicarb from rising and blunting respiratory drive
   .
   # ALL:
   On chronic immunosuppression s/p single cord blood transplantation.
   - Cont acyclovir ppx
   - Will not need to restart tacrolimus
   - [**Month (only) 51**] need to increase Stress dose steroids, per BMT
 will increase
   back up to 100mg hydrocort IV or switch to solumedrol
   - will convert to prednisone when her intestinal motility improves and
   her acute process resolves (home dose is 5 mg daily)
   - Appreciate BMT recs
   .
   # Hep B:
   - Cont lamivudine
   .
   #Constipation:
   Need to continue bowel regimen aggressively b/c of increased fentanyl w
   sedation now.
   - continue po narcan prn and standing docusate b/c still on fentanyl
   - lactulose, bisacodyl, senna, erythromycin PRN also

Summary:

The patient is a 52-year-old female with ALL, who underwent single cord blood transplantation and is currently in the ICU due to respiratory failure, sepsis, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis. She has a history of CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis. The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is on volume control ventilation with a tidal volume of 320cc, PEEP of 15cmH2O, and FiO2 of 90%. She is mildly desynchronous with the vent and has had a few trials of pressure control ventilation, which she did not tolerate.
* Sepsis/fever: The patient has had new fevers in the last 36 hours, and her sepsis is initially due to multifocal PNA. She has been off pressors for an extended period and is currently trending toward hypertension when sedation is weaned.
* Anemia: The patient has a large Hct drop, and her PTT is elevated, possibly due to subcutaneous heparin. She is being monitored for bleeding, and subcutaneous heparin has been held.
* Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium levels are elevated, and she is being treated with free water flushes with tube feeds.
* ARF: The patient's creatinine is stable at 0.9, and she is being monitored for any changes in her renal function.
* Elevated LFTs: The patient's liver function tests are elevated, and she is being monitored for any further changes.
* Non-gap acidosis: The patient's acidosis has resolved, and she is being monitored for any further changes.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is tenuous, and she may require further adjustments to her ventilation settings to improve her oxygenation.
2. Sepsis/fever: The patient's sepsis is ongoing, and she may require further antibiotics and monitoring to treat her infection.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia is a concern, and she may require further transfusions to improve her hemoglobin levels.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia is a concern, and she may require further treatment to correct her sodium levels.
5. ARF: The patient's renal function is stable, but she may require further monitoring to detect any changes in her renal function.
6. Elevated LFTs: The patient's liver function tests are elevated, and she may require further monitoring to detect any further changes.
7. Non-gap acidosis: The patient's acidosis has resolved, but she may require further monitoring to detect any further changes.

Based on the patient's current status and potential medical complications, the following plan is recommended:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust her ventilation settings as needed to improve her oxygenation.
2. Continue to treat the patient's sepsis with antibiotics and monitor her for any further changes in her infection.
3. Monitor the patient's anemia and consider further transfusions if necessary.
4. Continue to treat the patient's hypernatremia with free water flushes and monitor her sodium levels.
5. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust her medication dosages as necessary to optimize her renal function.
6. Monitor the patient's liver function tests and consider further treatment if necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's acidosis and adjust her treatment as necessary to maintain a stable acid-base balance.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 52-year-old female with acute myeloid leukemia (ALL) who has undergone chemotherapy and single cord blood transplantation. She is currently in the ICU due to pneumonia, sepsis, and respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: Hypoxemic respiratory failure, requiring high doses of sedation and mechanical ventilation.
* Hemodynamic status: Hypertension, with a blood pressure of 110/58 mmHg.
* Coagulation status: Elevated PTT, possibly due to subcutaneous heparin, and a large Hct drop.
* Renal status: Stable creatinine, but with a history of acute tubular necrosis (ATN).
* Liver function tests (LFTs): Elevated, with a concern for GVHD-induced hepatitis.
* Electrolyte status: Hypernatremia, with a sodium level of 146 mEq/L.
* Infection status: CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, and VRE UTI.
* Gastrointestinal status: Elevated LFTs, with a concern for GVHD-induced hepatitis and liver dysfunction.

The patient's medical complications are:

* Hypoxemic respiratory failure
* Sepsis
* ARDS
* Volume overload
* Worsening infection
* GVHD-induced hepatitis
* Liver dysfunction
* Hypernatremia
* Elevated LFTs
* Non-gap acidosis
* Constipation

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Mechanical ventilation with volume control and PEEP 15 cmH2O
* Sedation with fentanyl and midazolam
* Antibiotics for pneumonia and sepsis
* Anti-CMV therapy with micafungin
* Stress dose steroids for GVHD
* Prophylaxis for DVT and VAP
* Aggressive bowel regimen for constipation

The patient's laboratory results are:

* WBC: 10.4-14.4 K/uL
* Hct: 21.5-24.2%
* Plt: 06-643 mg/dL
* Cr: 0.9-1.1 mg/dL
* LFTs: Elevated
* Glucose: 120-143 mg/dL
* Albumin: 2.6 g/dL
* LDH: 440 IU/L
* Ca++: 7.7 mg/dL
* Mg++: 2.1 mg/dL
* PO4: 5.0 mg/dL

The patient's potential medical complications are:

* Pneumonia
* Sepsis
* ARDS
* Volume overload
* Worsening infection
* GVHD-induced hepatitis
* Liver dysfunction
* Hypernatremia
* Elevated LFTs
* Non-gap acidosis
* Constipation

The patient's code status is full code, and her disposition is ICU.

Summary:

The patient is a 52-year-old female with acute myeloid leukemia (ALL) who has undergone single cord blood transplantation and is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure. She has a history of CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis. The patient's current condition is complicated by hypoxemic respiratory failure, requiring high doses of sedation and mechanical ventilation.

The patient's hemodynamic status is stable, with a heart rate of 88 beats per minute and blood pressure of 110/58 mmHg. Her respiratory status is tenuous, with intermittent desaturation to 80s on 90% oxygen at a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 15 cmH2O. She has required high doses of sedation due to desynchrony with the ventilator.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin (Hb): 8.0 g/dL
* Hematocrit (Hct): 22.1%
* White blood cell count (WBC): 10.4 x 10^9/L
* Platelet count (Plt): 206 x 10^9/L
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 14.4 mg/dL
* Creatinine (Cr): 0.9 mg/dL
* Glucose: 143 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.7 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.6 g/dL
* LDH: 440 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.7 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.1 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 5.0 mg/dL

Potential medical complications:

1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is tenuous, and she requires high doses of sedation and mechanical ventilation. The patient may be at risk for further desaturation and respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a history of sepsis, and her current temperature is 100.3°F (38.1°C). She may be at risk for further sepsis and organ dysfunction.
3. Anemia: The patient's Hct has fallen to 21.5%, and she may require transfusion. Her platelet count is also low, and she may be at risk for bleeding.
4. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's Cr is elevated, and she may be at risk for further AKI.
5. Elevated liver enzymes: The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, and she may be at risk for further liver dysfunction.
6. Constipation: The patient is receiving high doses of fentanyl and may be at risk for constipation.
7. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level is elevated, and she may be at risk for further hypernatremia.
8. Volume overload: The patient's fluid balance is positive, and she may be at risk for volume overload.

Recommendations:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and sedation as necessary to manage the patient's respiratory status.
2. Monitor the patient's hemodynamic status and adjust therapy as necessary to maintain adequate perfusion.
3. Continue antimicrobial therapy as directed by the patient's healthcare team.
4. Monitor the patient's laboratory results and adjust therapy as necessary to manage her anemia, AKI, and elevated liver enzymes.
5. Continue bowel regimen as directed by the patient's healthcare team to manage constipation.
6. Monitor the patient's sodium level and adjust therapy as necessary to manage hypernatremia.
7. Monitor the patient's fluid balance and adjust therapy as necessary to manage volume overload.

TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
   - Hct drop to 21.5 --> recheck is 22 --> will recheck at 6pm and
   transfuse if Hct <21
   - Nursing noted upon turning pt that she had BRBPR (leaking, soaking
   the bed padding around the flexiseal) in early afternoon with a few
   clots
   - RUQ U/S
   - changed from PO ppx bactrim dose to treatment dose
   - switched from hydrocort to IV solumedrol for stress dose steroids
   (effective dose increased... but also taking away mineralocorticoid
   properties from hydrocortisone) (increased stress dose steroids, per
   BMT recs)
   - Repeat glucan and galactomannan drawn, per ID recs
   - restarting erythromycin for motility (w the incr fentanyl and higher
   residuals, etc...)
   - has had to be on increased sedation back up to 400 fentanyl and 8 of
   midaz --> concern of increasing fentanyl effect on motility... next
   time she gets agitated, we might try haldol 5mg to sedate without
   increasing fentanyl (last EKG QTc was not prolonged)
   - hypernatremia improving - decreased water flushes w tube feeds to
   Q6hrs (from Q4hrs) to decrease overall input
   - tried ventilating w larger tidal volumes briefly but plateau
   pressures were very high >40, so returned to previous settings

   - advance ET tube

   initially due to multifocal PNA, as seen on CT chest. Wide differential

s Cr stable now  0.9.  Cr above baseline.

Summary:

The patient is a 52-year-old female with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who underwent single cord blood transplantation and is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure. She has a history of CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis. The patient's current condition is complicated by hypoxemic respiratory failure, sepsis, and fever.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 100.3°F (37.9°C)
* Heart rate: 88 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 110/58 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 32 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 92%
* Central venous pressure: 23 mmHg

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 8.0 g/dL
* Hematocrit: 21.5% (down from 27.0% on the previous day)
* Platelet count: 14.4 K/uL
* White blood cell count: 10.4 K/uL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 143 mg/dL
* Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.7 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.6 g/dL
* LDH: 440 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.7 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.1 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 5.0 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Hypoxemic respiratory failure
* Sepsis
* Fever
* Anemia
* Acute renal failure
* Elevated liver enzymes
* CMV viremia
* Streptococcal bacteremia
* VRE UTI
* Suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis
* ALL

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continue lasix drip to decrease fluid balance
* Repeat chest x-ray and consider repeat chest CT
* Continue fentanyl and midazolam for sedation
* Add haloperidol PRN to decrease fentanyl/midazolam requirement
* Advance ET tube
* Continue on Volume Control ventilation with increased PEEP to 17
* Continue antibacterial coverage with vanc/meropenum
* Add voriconazole
* Continue Bactrim at treatment dose
* Monitor Hct and transfuse if <21
* Continue renally dosed medications
* Avoid nephrotoxins
* Continue lasix drip to decrease fluid balance
* Continue bowel regimen aggressively

Potential medical complications:

* Worsening respiratory failure
* Increased difficulty with ventilation
* Pneumonia/sepsis
* Sepsis-induced organ dysfunction
* Anemia
* Acute renal failure
* Elevated liver enzymes
* CMV viremia
* Streptococcal bacteremia
* VRE UTI
* Suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis
* ALL relapse

   52 yof ALL s/p cord blood transplant (>200 days) now with progressive

   RESPIRATORY FAILURE
 Net detreioration.  Attributed to infection and

   Continue with broad spectrum antibiotics
   (vanc/meropenem/mycafungin/Bactrim).  Adjust ETT.  Continue mechanical
   ventilation, hope to decrease FiO2 to <60% if possible, and increase
   PEEP as tolerated to improve oxygenation.  [**Month (only) 51**] benefit from esophogeal
   balloon placement to monitor Monitor CXR.
   PULMONARY INFILTRATES
 diffuse, pleural effusions.  Attributble to
   infection, but may in part related to net positive fluid balance.
   Continue antibiotics, continue net diuresis.  Consider diagnostic
   bronchoscopy.
   HYPERNATREMIA
 improved with free water.  Monitor Na.
   SEPSIS
 resolved, remains off pressors.   Initially due to multifocal
   PNA, as seen on CT chest.
   ACUTE RENAL FAILURE
 attributed to ATN.  Resolving.  Continue monitor
   BUN, creatinine,
   ELEVATED LFTs -- Currently stable.  Monitor LFTs.
   FLUIDS
 net positive.  Desire net negative daily fluid balance.
   ALL -- s/p cord blood transplantation.   BMTx team following.
   HEPATITIS B -- Continue lamivudine
   ANEMIA
 Normocytic.  Hct stable.  Transfuse for Hct < 21

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 52-year-old individual who has undergone a cord blood transplant over 200 days ago and is currently experiencing progressive hypoxemic respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.7°C (99.8°F)
* Heart rate: 91 bpm (normal range: 80-94 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 110/58 mmHg (normal range: 77/0-0 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 32 breaths per minute (normal range: 29-32 breaths per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 96%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 10.4-14.4 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 8.0 g/dL
* Platelet count: 206 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.9-1.1 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 30-31 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: sodium 143-159 mmol/L, potassium 3.5-4.8 mmol/L, calcium 7.7-8.1 mg/dL, magnesium 1.8-2.2 mg/dL, phosphorus 4.8-5.2 mg/dL
* Liver function tests: ALT 106 IU/L, AST 71 IU/L, alkaline phosphatase 312 IU/L, total bilirubin 0.4 mg/dL
* Coagulation studies: PT 11.4 seconds, PTT 34.0 seconds, INR 0.9
* Fibrinogen: 643 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.7 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.6 g/dL
* LDH: 555 IU/L

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* General appearance: well-nourished, no acute distress
* Respiratory: bilateral wheezing, rhonchi, and decreased breath sounds
* Cardiovascular: normal sinus rhythm, blood pressure 110/58 mmHg
* Abdomen: soft, non-tender, bowel sounds present
* Extremities: bilateral lower extremity edema, 2+ (mild)

The patient's diagnosis is:

* Respiratory failure
* ARDS
* Pulmonary infiltrates
* Hypernatremia
* Sepsis (resolved)
* Acute renal failure (attributed to acute tubular necrosis)
* Elevated liver function tests
* Fluid overload

The patient's plan includes:

* Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics
* Adjust endotracheal tube
* Continue mechanical ventilation
* Monitor CXR
* Consider diagnostic bronchoscopy
* Continue net diuresis
* Monitor sodium levels
* Continue lamivudine for hepatitis B
* Transfuse for hematocrit < 21%
* Monitor liver function tests
* Continue prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia.

The patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management in the intensive care unit (ICU).

   RESPIRATORY FAILURE
 Net detreioration.  Attributed to infection and

   Continue with broad spectrum antibiotics
   (vanc/meropenem/mycafungin/Bactrim).  Adjust ETT.  Continue mechanical

 diffuse, pleural effusions.  Attributble to

   Continue antibiotics, continue net diuresis.  Consider diagnostic

 attributed to ATN.  Resolving.  Continue monitor

 net positive.  Desire net negative daily fluid balance.

Summary:

The patient is a 52-year-old male with acute respiratory failure, attributed to infection and possible cardiogenic pulmonary edema, who has undergone cord blood transplantation over 200 days ago. He is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated with increasing FiO2 requirements. His condition has deteriorated, and he is at risk of developing acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). He also has hypernatremia, which has improved with free water administration, and acute renal failure attributed to acute tubular necrosis (ATN). His liver function tests (LFTs) are elevated, and he has anemia, which is being managed with transfusions.

Potential medical complications:

1. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): The patient's condition is deteriorating, and he is at risk of developing ARDS, which can lead to respiratory failure and death.
2. Sepsis: The patient has sepsis, which can lead to organ failure and death if not managed promptly and effectively.
3. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient has acute renal failure, which can lead to chronic kidney disease, electrolyte imbalances, and increased risk of cardiovascular events.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia can lead to dehydration, electrolyte imbalances, and increased risk of seizures and cardiac arrhythmias.
5. Liver dysfunction: The patient's elevated LFTs can indicate liver dysfunction, which can lead to coagulopathy, bleeding, and increased risk of infections.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia can lead to decreased oxygen delivery to tissues, fatigue, and increased risk of infections.
7. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's nutritional support is limited, which can lead to malnutrition, decreased immune function, and increased risk of infections.
8. Fluid overload: The patient has net positive fluid balance, which can lead to fluid overload, electrolyte imbalances, and increased risk of cardiovascular events.
9. Cardiogenic pulmonary edema: The patient's condition may be attributed to cardiogenic pulmonary edema, which can lead to respiratory failure and death if not managed promptly and effectively.
10. Infection: The patient has an infection, which can lead to sepsis, organ failure, and death if not managed promptly and effectively.

   Assessment and Plan
   52 yof ALL s/p cord blood transplant (>200 days ago) on chronic
   immunosupression (tacrolimus and low dose prednisone) on intermittent
   pentamidine PCP prophylaxis now with hypoxemic respiratory failure and
   ARDS, intubated and hypotensive. LOS positive approx + 13 L.
   Impression/plan - progressive hypoxemic respiratory failure over past 2
   days. Continue with broad spectrum abx with vanc/meropenem and readded
   mycafungin. Consider restarting Bactrim for PCP though unlikely given
   negative Bglucan and neg BAL.
   Did not tolerate PSV and by report didn't do as well with APRV and PCV
   in past. Still requiring high PEEP and FiO2 but will tolerate a lower
   pO2 of 55-60. Much of her improvement has resulted from aggressive
   fluid removal now that her ARF and shock have resolved but likely
   mobilizing 3rd spaced fluid to her lungs, probably bilat effusions.
   Lowered sedation has worsened ability to oxygenate. C/w lasix drip +/-
   albumin for diuresis. Hypernatremia likely due to diuresis - will
   change meds back to D5. Abnormal LFTs likely tacrolimus, BMT following
   closely, on steroids.  Anemia is concerning. Agree with keeping Hct>21,
   transfuse prn, check guaiac, if concern for bleed, d/c SCH. Elevated
   PTT
 will decrease SCH dose. Follow all cultures. Too tenuous to
   bronch.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 52-year-old female with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who underwent a cord blood transplant over 200 days ago and is currently experiencing hypoxemic respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). She is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 90% and PEEP of 15 cmH2O.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.7°C, heart rate of 91 bpm, and blood pressure of 110/58 mmHg. Her respiratory rate is 32 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 96%. Her cardiac rhythm is normal sinus rhythm.

The patient's physical examination reveals bilateral lower extremity edema, but no other significant findings. Her laboratory results show anemia, elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and abnormal liver function tests (LFTs). Her blood cultures are pending.

The patient's assessment and plan include continued broad-spectrum antibiotics, including vancomycin and meropenem, as well as readded mycangin for fungal prophylaxis. She is also receiving intermittent pentamidine for Pneumocystis jirovecii prophylaxis. The patient's hypotension is being treated with fluids, and her hypernatremia is being managed with D5 fluids. Her anemia is being monitored, and she is being transfused as needed.

The patient's ICU care plan includes:

* Nutrition: Tube feeding with a goal of 1,000 calories per day
* Glycemic control: Target blood glucose of 100-150 mg/dL
* Lines: Arterial line, central venous catheter, and peripheral IV lines
* Prophylaxis: DVT prophylaxis with boots, stress ulcer prophylaxis with PPI, and VAP prophylaxis with HOB elevation, mouth care, and daily wake-up
* Medications: Tacrolimus, prednisone, and mycangin

The patient's code status is full code, and her disposition is ICU.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS and hypoxemic respiratory failure may worsen, requiring increased respiratory support or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
2. Sepsis: The patient's broad-spectrum antibiotics may not cover all potential pathogens, increasing the risk of sepsis and multi-organ failure.
3. Bleeding: The patient's anemia and abnormal LFTs may increase her risk of bleeding, particularly if she is transfused or requires invasive procedures.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's hypotension and abnormal LFTs may increase her risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiac failure.
5. Infection: The patient's immunosuppressed state and prolonged ICU stay may increase her risk of infection, particularly with opportunistic pathogens.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's tube feeding and potential for malnutrition may increase her risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as diarrhea or constipation.
7. Renal complications: The patient's acute kidney injury and potential for chronic kidney disease may increase her risk of renal complications, such as acute tubular necrosis or chronic kidney disease.

Overall, the patient's critical illness requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications.

   52-year-old female with ALL s/p chemo and single cord blood
   transplantation complicated by CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia,
   VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis who presents with
   pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure.

   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure:
   Respiratory status still tenuous, with intermittent desaturation to 80s
   on 90% O2 at PEEP 15 cm H20. Has required high doses of sedation due to
   desynchrony with vent.  Ddx for increased difficulty with ventilation
   includes ARDS, volume overload, worsening infection.
   - continue lasix gtt
   - repeat chest x-ray
   - consider repeat chest CT
 could not tolerating [**2-26**] hypoxemia
   - continue on Volume Control ventilation: increase PEEP to 17
   - continue fentanyl and midazolam for sedation. Can add haloperidol PRN
   in order to decrease fentanyl/midazolam requirement. Will need to check
   QTc.
   .
   # Airway:
   ET tube noted to be 7 cm above carina.
   - advance ET tube
   .
   # Sepsis / Fever:
   Tmax 100.3 in past 24 hours.  Maintaining BP off pressors.  Sepsis
   initially due to multifocal PNA, as seen on CT chest. Wide differential
   given immunosuppression but influenza and other respiratory virus panel
   negative; AFB smear on BAL was negative, urine legionella negative.
   Culture from BAL with less than 1,000 colonies, Gram stain negative for
   PMN
s or organisms. BAL: prelim negative for CMV.  New fever concerning
   for a worsening pulmonary process or a new source of infection.  C diff
   [**11-17**] negative.  First glucan and galactomannan negative.
   - d/c micafungin
   - add voriconazole (day 1 = [**2114-11-19**])
   - Empiric broad antibacterial coverage with vanc/meropenum, day 9 of 14
   (day 1 = [**11-10**])
   - Continue Bactrim at treatment dose
   - F/U CMV VL, EBV PCR, repeat glucan, repeat galactomannan
   .
   # Anemia:
   Hct fell from 27.0 on [**11-17**] to 21.5 on [**11-18**].  Did have elevated PTT
   122 on [**11-18**], possible [**2-26**] to subQ heparin, now improved. Has GI
   bleeding (noted to have BRBPR).
   - monitor Hct
   - Active T+S
   - Transfuse for Hct < 21
   .
   # ARF: patient
s Cr stable now  0.9.  Cr above baseline.
   - renally dose meds
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   - continue lasix drip to decrease LOS fluid balance, goal of UOP
   greater than 150cc per hour (b/c getting at least 100cc/hr IN)
   .
   # Elevated LFTs: Difficult to assess as patient has had multiple
   hemolyzed lab specimens
   - f/u RUQ ultrasound
   .
   # ALL:
   On chronic immunosuppression s/p single cord blood transplantation.
   - Cont acyclovir ppx
   - Will not need to restart tacrolimus
   - on solumedrol
   - Appreciate BMT recs
   .
   # Hep B:
   - Cont lamivudine
   .
   #Constipation:
   Need to continue bowel regimen aggressively b/c of increased fentanyl w
   sedation now.
   - continue po narcan prn and standing docusate b/c still on fentanyl
   - lactulose, bisacodyl, senna, erythromycin PRN also

 will hold, then cut down dose due to elevated PTT

Summary:

The patient is a 52-year-old female with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who has undergone chemotherapy and single cord blood transplantation. She has developed complications, including CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis. She is currently in the ICU with hypoxemic respiratory failure, sepsis, and fever.

Recent events include:

* The patient's ABG showed decreased oxygen saturation and increased carbon dioxide levels, requiring increased oxygen therapy and adjustment of ventilator settings.
* The patient's ET tube was advanced 3cm, and an attempt was made to perform an esophageal balloon, but it was unsuccessful due to desaturation.
* A non-contrast chest CT was attempted, but the patient desaturated on the way to the CT scanner.
* The patient's RUQ ultrasound showed a normal ultrasonographic appearance of the liver with no evidence of biliary dilatation, and a 5mm gallbladder polyp.
* The patient's chest x-ray showed widespread pulmonary opacities with slight interval improvement, and small focal lucency at the left base that may represent a small loculated anteromedial pneumothorax.

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure is likely to continue, and she may require further adjustment of ventilator settings and oxygen therapy.
* Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely to continue, and she may require further antibiotic therapy and supportive care.
* Fever: The patient's fever is likely to continue, and she may require further evaluation and treatment for the underlying cause.
* Hepatitis: The patient's suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis may require further evaluation and treatment.
* ARF: The patient's acute kidney injury is likely to continue, and she may require further management with dialysis and medication adjustments.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely to continue, and she may require further transfusion and treatment.
* Constipation: The patient's constipation is likely to continue, and she may require further management with bowel regimen and laxatives.

Plan:

* Continue lasix drip to decrease fluid balance and increase urine output.
* Repeat chest x-ray and consider repeat chest CT to evaluate the patient's lung disease.
* Continue fentanyl and midazolam for sedation and consider adding haloperidol PRN to decrease fentanyl/midazolam requirement.
* Continue voriconazole and empiric broad antibacterial coverage with vanc/meropenum.
* Monitor Hct and transfuse for Hct < 21.
* Continue lasix drip to decrease fluid balance and increase urine output.
* Consider repeat RUQ ultrasound to evaluate the patient's liver function.
* Continue acyclovir prophylaxis and lamivudine for hepatitis B.
* Continue bowel regimen aggressively to manage constipation.

Summary:

The patient is a 47-kg male admitted to the ICU with a history of cancer, diabetes, and BMT. He has been experiencing respiratory distress, requiring mechanical ventilation and high FiO2 levels. He has also developed widespread pulmonary opacities, pleural effusions, and a small focal lucency at the left base, which may represent a small loculated anteromedial pneumothorax. His blood work shows elevated LFTs, and he has been receiving antibiotics and antifungals. He has also been experiencing constipation and hypotension.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is deteriorating, with increased FiO2 requirements and decreased compliance. Pneumothorax or further lung injury may worsen his condition.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated LFTs and WBC count suggest potential sepsis, which may lead to organ dysfunction and increased mortality.
3. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's constipation may lead to bowel obstruction or perforation, and his hypotension may worsen his gastrointestinal bleeding risk.
4. Infection: The patient's prolonged stay in the ICU and immunosuppressive therapy may increase his risk of infection, including ventilator-associated pneumonia.
5. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's hypotension may worsen his organ dysfunction and increase his risk of cardiac arrest.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's prolonged sedation and hypotension may lead to neurological damage or worsening of his underlying neurological condition.
7. Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD): The patient's elevated LFTs and WBC count may indicate GVHD, which can lead to multi-organ failure and increased mortality.
8. Malignancy progression: The patient's underlying cancer may be progressing, leading to further organ dysfunction and decreased quality of life.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely, adjusting his ventilator settings as needed to optimize his oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Consider adding antibiotics to his regimen to address potential sepsis.
3. Manage the patient's constipation with laxatives and stool softeners to prevent bowel obstruction or perforation.
4. Monitor the patient's blood work closely for signs of infection or GVHD, and adjust his treatment plan accordingly.
5. Consider consulting with a gastroenterologist to optimize the patient's nutrition and prevent further gastrointestinal complications.
6. Monitor the patient's hemodynamic status closely, adjusting his fluid and vasopressor therapy as needed to maintain adequate perfusion.
7. Consider consulting with a neurologist to optimize the patient's sedation and prevent neurological complications.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's underlying cancer, adjusting his treatment plan as needed to optimize his outcomes.

   Mono:7.3 %, Eos:0.6 %, Fibrinogen:643 mg/dL, Lactic Acid:1.7 mmol/L,

   Assessment and Plan
   52-year-old female with ALL s/p chemo and single cord blood
   transplantation complicated by CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia,
   VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis who presents with
   pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS:
   Some of patient difficulty with oxygenation may be related to
   dysynchrony with vent. Ventillator setting themselves are appropriate,
   although patient is requiring very high FIO2 (100%).
   - trial of propofol -> dropped pressure with no improvement in
   synchrony
   - paralyze with cisatracurium -> improved oxygenation
   - repeat chest CT if hypoxemia improved with paralysis
   - continue on Volume Control ventilation with tv 270, rate 30, PEEP 15,
   FIO2 100%
   - attempt to decrease FIO2 if SaO2 improves with paralysis
   - continue fentanyl/midazolam
   .
   # Sepsis / Fever:
   Afebrile.  Maintaining BP off pressors.  Sepsis initially due to
   multifocal PNA, as seen on CT chest. Wide differential given
   immunosuppression but influenza and other respiratory virus panel
   negative; AFB smear on BAL was negative, urine legionella negative.
   Culture from BAL with less than 1,000 colonies, Gram stain negative for
   PMN
s or organisms. BAL: prelim negative for CMV.  C diff [**11-17**]
   negative.  First glucan and galactomannan negative.
   - f/u ID recs
   - on meropenem/vanc (treat for 14-day course, day 1 = [**11-10**])
   - on voriconazole (day 1 = [**2114-11-19**])
   - Continue Bactrim at treatment dose
   - F/U pending blood cultures; acid fast, fungal, viral BAL cultures,
   repeat glucan, repeat galactomannan
   .
   # Anemia:
   Hct stable. No recurrence of GI bleeding.
   - monitor Hct
   - Active T+S
   - Transfuse for Hct < 21
   .
   # ARF: Cr above baseline but stable.
   - renally dose meds
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   - continue lasix drip to decrease LOS fluid balance, goal of UOP
   greater than 150cc per hour (b/c getting at least 100cc/hr IN)
   - consider adding metolozone if not diuresing well
   .
   # Elevated LFTs: Etiology unclear. [**Name2 (NI) 3234**] shows normal liver, biliary
   system except for gallbladder polyp.
   - trend LFTs
   .
   # ALL:
   On chronic immunosuppression s/p single cord blood transplantation.
   - Cont acyclovir ppx
   - Will not need to restart tacrolimus
   - on solumedrol
   - Appreciate BMT recs
   .
   # Hep B:
   - Cont lamivudine
   .
   #Constipation:
   Need to continue bowel regimen aggressively b/c of increased fentanyl w
   sedation now.
   - continue po narcan prn and standing docusate b/c still on fentanyl
   - lactulose, bisacodyl, senna, erythromycin PRN also
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Boost Glucose Control (Full) - [**2114-11-18**] 05:47 AM 48 mL/hour
   Glycemic Control:  Insulin sliding scale
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2114-11-9**] 11:00 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2114-11-10**] 02:00 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SQ Heparin
 restarting at 5000 units daily (held for 2 days in
   setting of elevated PTT), pneumoboots
   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP:  bundle
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments: Husband (cantonese speaking) and son (speaks
   english)
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: ICU

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 52-year-old female with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who has undergone single cord blood transplantation and is currently experiencing complications. The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated due to hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS.

The patient's respiratory status is concerning, with widespread pulmonary opacities on chest CT and a high FIO2 requirement of 100%. The patient has desatted on multiple occasions, including during attempts to perform an esophageal balloon and during transport to the CT scan. The patient's ABG results show a partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 70 mmHg, indicating significant hypoxemia.

The patient's cardiac status is also concerning, with a history of CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, and VRE UTI. The patient's blood pressure is stable, but the patient's heart rate is slightly elevated.

The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) are elevated, but the etiology is unclear. The patient's gallbladder is normal, except for a small polyp.

The patient's renal function is stable, but the patient is at risk for acute kidney injury (AKI) due to the use of nephrotoxic medications.

The patient's immunosuppressive medications include tacrolimus, which has been discontinued. The patient is also taking voriconazole, which has been started in place of micafungin.

The patient's constipation is a concern, as the patient is receiving high doses of fentanyl and sedation. The patient's bowel regimen should be continued aggressively to prevent constipation.

The patient's ICU care includes prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient's code status is full code, and the patient's disposition is to remain in the ICU.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS is a significant concern, and the patient may require further interventions to improve oxygenation.
2. Sepsis: The patient's history of CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, and VRE UTI makes the patient at risk for sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ dysfunction.
3. AKI: The patient's use of nephrotoxic medications and underlying renal dysfunction make the patient at risk for AKI.
4. Hepatic dysfunction: The patient's elevated LFTs are a concern, and the patient may require further evaluation and treatment for liver dysfunction.
5. Constipation: The patient's constipation is a concern, and the patient may require further interventions to prevent constipation.
6. DVT: The patient's prophylaxis for DVT is important, as the patient is at risk for developing a DVT due to immobility and underlying medical conditions.
7. VAP: The patient's prophylaxis for VAP is important, as the patient is at risk for developing VAP due to the use of mechanical ventilation.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 52-year-old female with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who has undergone chemotherapy and single cord blood transplantation. She has developed complications including:

1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS: The patient is experiencing difficulty with oxygenation, which may be related to dysynchrony with the ventilator. She requires high FIO2 (100%) and has widespread pulmonary opacities on chest CT.
2. Sepsis/Fever: The patient has a Tmax of 100.3°F in the past 24 hours and has been febrile for several days. She has a wide differential diagnosis, including pneumonia, influenza, and other respiratory viruses, but initial tests have been negative. She has a new fever, which is concerning for a worsening pulmonary process or a new source of infection.
3. Anemia: The patient's Hct has fallen from 27.0 to 21.5, and she has had elevated PTT, which may be related to subQ heparin. She has GI bleeding and is being actively transfused.
4. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient's Cr is stable at 0.9, but above baseline. She is being renally dosed with medications and is being monitored for nephrotoxins.
5. Elevated Liver Function Tests (LFTs): The patient has elevated LFTs, which may be related to hemolyzed lab specimens. She is being monitored with RUQ ultrasound.
6. Constipation: The patient is at risk for constipation due to increased fentanyl use and sedation. She is being treated with bowel regimen and laxatives.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS may worsen, leading to further respiratory compromise.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may progress, leading to organ failure or death.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, leading to further transfusion requirements and potential bleeding complications.
4. ARF: The patient's ARF may progress, leading to further kidney damage or failure.
5. LFT elevation: The patient's LFT elevation may worsen, leading to liver dysfunction or failure.
6. Constipation: The patient's constipation may worsen, leading to bowel obstruction or perforation.

To address these potential complications, the patient should be closely monitored for signs of respiratory failure, sepsis, anemia, ARF, LFT elevation, and constipation. She should also be treated with antibiotics, antivirals, and other medications as necessary. Additionally, the patient's family should be educated on her condition and the importance of following the treatment plan.

<|begin_of_text|><|start_header_id|>system<|end_header_id|>

You are a Medical Specialist capable of analyzing complex medical cases. To do that, you will carefully review the physician's daily progress note for a patient in the ICU detailing the patient's health progress in the ICU. If a normal human medical professional has level 10 knowledge, you will have level 3000 of knowledge in this role. As it's crucial for the patient's well-being, please ensure accurate assessments because if you don't, the patient's condition could worsen. Take pride in your work and give it your best. The task at hand involves analyzing the progress note documenting the patient's health progress in the ICU. Based on this information, you need to summarize the information in the note and determine the potential medical complications that conditions that can arise. Do not tell your limitations. Do not echo my prompt. Please do not remind me what I asked you for. Do not apologize. Do not self-reference. Get to the point precisely and accurately.<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

   Mono:7.3 %, Eos:0.6 %, Fibrinogen:643 mg/dL, Lactic Acid:1.7 mmol/L,
   Albumin:2.7 g/dL, LDH:378 IU/L, Ca++:8.0 mg/dL, Mg++:2.3 mg/dL, PO4:3.7
   mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   52 yof ALL s/p cord blood transplant (>200 days) now with progressive
   hypoxemic respiratory failure and ARDS.
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE
 Net deterioration. Marked hypoxemia.   Attributed
   to ARDS predominately, on background of infection and possible
   cardiogenic pulmonary edema.  Continue with broad spectrum antibiotics
   (vanc/meropenem/voriconazole/Bactrim).   Continue mechanical
   ventilation, hope to decrease FiO2 to <60% if possible, and increase
   PEEP as tolerated to improve oxygenation.  [**Month (only) 51**] benefit from esophogeal
   balloon placement to monitor Monitor CXR.  Likely will require
   paralysis to reduce work of breathing.
   PULMONARY INFILTRATES
 diffuse, pleural effusions.  Attributble to
   infection, but may in part related to net positive fluid balance.  Also
   concerned for GVHD.  Continue antibiotics, continue net diuresis.
   Consider diagnostic bronchoscopy, but high risk currently (marginal
   oxygenation on 100% FiO2).
   HYPERNATREMIA
 improved with free water.  Monitor Na.
   SEPSIS
 resolved, remains off pressors.   Initially due to multifocal
   PNA, as seen on CT chest.
   ACUTE RENAL FAILURE
 attributed to ATN.  Resolving.  Continue monitor
   BUN, creatinine,
   HYPOKALEMIA -- replete to K >4.0
   ELEVATED LFTs -- Possible related to GVHD, with contribution of
   medications.  Currently stable.  Monitor LFTs.
   FLUIDS
 net positive.  Desire net negative daily fluid balance.
   ALL -- s/p cord blood transplantation.   BMTx team following.
   HEPATITIS B -- Continue lamivudine
   ANEMIA
 Normocytic.  Hct stable.  Transfuse for Hct < 21.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Boost Glucose Control (Full) - [**2114-11-20**] 12:00 AM 20 mL/hour
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2114-11-9**] 11:00 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2114-11-10**] 02:00 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Boots(Systemic anticoagulation: None)
   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care, Daily wake up, RSBI
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition :ICU
   Total time spent: 45 minutes
   Patient is critically ill

Summary:

The patient is a 52-year-old male with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who underwent cord blood transplantation over 200 days ago. He is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated due to progressive hypoxemic respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). His respiratory status has deteriorated, with marked hypoxemia attributed to ARDS, infection, and possible cardiogenic pulmonary edema. He is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics and mechanical ventilation, with a goal of decreasing FiO2 to less than 60% and increasing PEEP as tolerated to improve oxygenation.

The patient has several comorbidities, including hypernatremia, acute renal failure attributed to acute tubular necrosis (ATN), and elevated liver function tests (LFTs) possibly related to graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) and medication side effects. He is also experiencing anemia, with a stable hematocrit.

The patient's fluid status is net positive, and the healthcare team aims to achieve a net negative daily fluid balance. He is receiving nutrition via a feeding tube, and his glucose control is being monitored.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status continues to deteriorate, and he may require further interventions to improve oxygenation, such as increasing PEEP or using extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
2. ARDS: The patient's ARDS may progress, leading to further respiratory failure and potentially requiring intubation and mechanical ventilation.
3. Infection: The patient is at risk for further infections, particularly given his immunocompromised state and the presence of a central venous catheter.
4. GVHD: The patient's elevated LFTs may be related to GVHD, which can have significant consequences if left untreated.
5. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute renal failure may progress, leading to further complications, such as electrolyte imbalances and fluid overload.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, requiring further transfusions and potentially impacting his overall health.
7. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may persist or worsen, leading to complications such as seizures, coma, or death.
8. Fluid overload: The patient's net positive fluid balance may lead to fluid overload, potentially causing respiratory distress, cardiac compromise, or other complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 52-year-old male with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who underwent cord blood transplantation over 200 days ago. He is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) with progressive hypoxemic respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). He is intubated and mechanically ventilated, requiring high FiO2 (100%) and high positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) to maintain oxygenation. His chest X-ray shows diffuse pulmonary infiltrates and pleural effusions, which are attributed to ARDS. He also has hypernatremia, which has improved with free water administration. His liver function tests (LFTs) are elevated, which may be related to graft-versus-host disease (GVHD). He has acute renal failure, which is attributed to acute tubular necrosis (ATN), and is receiving lasix drip to manage fluid balance. He is also receiving antibiotics to cover possible infection.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Prolonged respiratory failure and ARDS, which may lead to further deterioration in oxygenation and respiratory function.
2. Infection, which may be exacerbated by the patient's immunocompromised state and prolonged mechanical ventilation.
3. Cardiogenic pulmonary edema, which may worsen respiratory failure and oxygenation.
4. GVHD, which may cause further liver damage and multi-organ dysfunction.
5. Acute kidney injury, which may progress to chronic kidney disease or require dialysis.
6. Hypernatremia, which may lead to central nervous system complications if not managed promptly.
7. Anemia, which may worsen respiratory failure and require transfusions.
8. Sepsis, which may recur if not managed aggressively.

Recommendations:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and adjust FiO2 and PEEP to optimize oxygenation.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory function closely and consider diagnostic bronchoscopy to rule out infection.
3. Manage hypernatremia with free water administration and monitor sodium levels.
4. Continue antibiotics to cover possible infection and adjust therapy based on culture results.
5. Monitor LFTs and consider liver function tests to assess for GVHD.
6. Continue lasix drip to manage fluid balance and monitor BUN and creatinine levels.
7. Consider transfusions for anemia if Hct falls below 21.
8. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and consider dialysis if acute kidney injury worsens.

Summary:

The patient is a 52-year-old male with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who underwent cord blood transplantation over 200 days ago. He is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated due to progressive hypoxemic respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The patient's condition has deteriorated, with marked hypoxemia attributed to ARDS, possible infection, and possible cardiogenic pulmonary edema. He is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics and mechanical ventilation, with the goal of decreasing FiO2 to <60% and increasing PEEP as tolerated to improve oxygenation.

The patient has several comorbidities, including:

1. Respiratory failure with ARDS
2. Hypoxemia
3. Hypernatremia
4. Sepsis (resolved)
5. Acute renal failure (attributed to ATN) with resolving creatinine levels
6. Elevated liver function tests (LFTs) possibly related to graft-versus-host disease (GVHD)
7. Anemia (normocytic) with stable hemoglobin levels
8. Fluid overload with a net positive fluid balance

Plan:

1. Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics and adjust ETT as needed
2. Maintain mechanical ventilation and aim to decrease FiO2 to <60% and increase PEEP as tolerated
3. Monitor for signs of infection and adjust antibiotics as needed
4. Consider diagnostic bronchoscopy, but currently high-risk in the context of marginal oxygenation
5. Continue to monitor and manage hypernatremia, sepsis, and acute renal failure
6. Monitor LFTs for signs of GVHD
7. Transfuse blood products as needed to maintain hemoglobin levels >21%
8. Continue to monitor and manage fluid overload, aiming for a net negative daily fluid balance

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Further deterioration of respiratory function, leading to increased risk of mortality
2. Development of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
3. Increased risk of bleeding due to thrombocytopenia
4. Development of sepsis or septic shock
5. Further progression of acute renal failure
6. Development of liver dysfunction or failure due to GVHD
7. Increased risk of cardiac complications due to cardiogenic pulmonary edema
8. Development of electrolyte imbalances, particularly hypernatremia and hyperkalemia.

   Assessment and Plan
   52-year-old female with ALL s/p chemo and single cord blood
   transplantation complicated by CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia,
   VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis who presents with
   pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS:
   Some of patient difficulty with oxygenation may be related to
   dysynchrony with vent. After paralysis w/ cisatracurium patient was
   oxygenating better from 88% to 93%.  Esophageal balloon done, PEEP
   already maxed at 15. On rounds, transpulmonary pressure equalized at
   zero (15 and -15).  Ventillator setting themselves are appropriate, and
   patient is at 80% FiO2.
   - paralyze with cisatracurium -> improved oxygenation
   - repeat chest CT if hypoxemia improved with paralysis
   - continue on Volume Control ventilation with tv 270, rate 30, PEEP 15,
   FIO2 80%
   - attempt to decrease FIO2 if SaO2 improves with paralysis
   - continue fentanyl/midazolam
   .
   # Sepsis / Fever:
   Afebrile.  Maintaining BP off pressors.  Sepsis initially due to
   multifocal PNA, as seen on CT chest. Wide differential given
   immunosuppression but influenza and other respiratory virus panel
   negative; AFB smear on BAL was negative, urine legionella negative.
   Culture from BAL with less than 1,000 colonies, Gram stain negative for
   PMN
s or organisms. BAL: prelim negative for CMV.  C diff [**11-17**]
   negative.  First glucan and galactomannan negative.
   - repeat BAL send for gram stain, Cx, CMV, respiratory virus panel
   - f/u ID recs
   - on meropenem/vanc (treat for 14-day course, day 1 = [**11-10**])
   - on voriconazole (day 1 = [**2114-11-19**])
   - Continue Bactrim at treatment dose
   - F/U pending blood cultures; acid fast, fungal, viral BAL cultures,
   repeat glucan, repeat galactomannan
   .
   # Anemia:
   Hct stable. No recurrence of GI bleeding.
   - monitor Hct
   - Active T+S
   - Transfuse for Hct < 21
   .
   # ARF: Cr above baseline but stable.
   - renally dose meds
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   - continue lasix drip to decrease LOS fluid balance, goal of UOP
   greater than 150cc per hour (b/c getting at least 100cc/hr IN)
   - consider adding metolozone if not diuresing well
   .
   # Elevated LFTs: Etiology unclear. [**Name2 (NI) 3234**] shows normal liver, biliary
   system except for gallbladder polyp.
   - trend LFTs
   .
   # ALL:
   On chronic immunosuppression s/p single cord blood transplantation.
   - Cont acyclovir ppx
   - Will not need to restart tacrolimus
   - on solumedrol
   - Appreciate BMT recs
   .
   # Hep B:
   - Cont lamivudine
   .
   #Constipation:
   Need to continue bowel regimen aggressively b/c of increased fentanyl w
   sedation now.
   - continue po narcan prn and standing docusate b/c still on fentanyl
   - lactulose, bisacodyl, senna, erythromycin PRN also
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Boost Glucose Control (Full) - [**2114-11-18**] 05:47 AM 48 mL/hour
   Glycemic Control:  Insulin sliding scale

   Multi Lumen - [**2114-11-9**] 11:00 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2114-11-10**] 02:00 AM

   DVT: SQ Heparin
 restarting at 5000 units daily (held for 2 days in

   VAP:  bundle

   english)

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 52-year-old female with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who underwent single cord blood transplantation. She has been complicated by CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis. She presents with pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is intubated and on volume control ventilation with a tidal volume of 270 mL, rate of 30 breaths per minute, PEEP of 15 cmH2O, and FiO2 of 80%. She has been paralyzed with cisatracurium, which has improved her oxygenation from 88% to 93%.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient's blood pressure is maintained off pressors, and she has a central venous pressure of 10 mmHg.
* Renal status: The patient has acute kidney injury with a creatinine level above baseline but stable.
* Hepatic status: The patient has elevated liver function tests (LFTs) with an unclear etiology.
* Hematological status: The patient has anemia with a hemoglobin level of 7.9 g/dL, and her platelet count is 226 K/uL.
* Infection status: The patient has sepsis due to multifocal pneumonia, and her BAL cultures are pending.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and she requires ongoing support with mechanical ventilation. The risk of respiratory failure is high, particularly if her FiO2 is decreased or if she develops further respiratory complications.
* Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is ongoing, and she is at risk of developing further complications such as organ dysfunction, septic shock, and death.
* Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury is stable, but she is at risk of further deterioration if her kidney function does not improve.
* Hepatic dysfunction: The patient's elevated LFTs are of concern, and she is at risk of developing further liver dysfunction or failure.
* Bleeding: The patient's platelet count is low, and she is at risk of bleeding, particularly if she requires further surgical or invasive procedures.

In terms of management, the patient requires ongoing close monitoring and management of her respiratory, cardiovascular, renal, and hematological status. She also requires ongoing treatment for her sepsis, including antibiotics and antifungal therapy. Her elevated LFTs require further investigation and management, and her anemia requires ongoing monitoring and potential transfusion support.

   rounds:
   * Question of muscle paralytics vs. adding another [**Doctor Last Name **] such as
   methadone to versad and fentanyl.  Decision was made not to go with

   Assessment and Plan
   52-year-old female with ALL s/p chemo and single cord blood
   transplantation complicated by CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia,
   VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis who presents with
   pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS:
   Some of patient difficulty with oxygenation may be related to
   dysynchrony with vent. Ventillator setting themselves are appropriate,
   although patient is requiring very high FIO2 (100%).
   - trial of propofol -> dropped pressure with no improvement in
   synchrony
   - paralyze with cisatracurium -> improved oxygenation
   - repeat chest CT if hypoxemia improved with paralysis
   - continue on Volume Control ventilation with tv 270, rate 30, PEEP 15,
   FIO2 100%
   - attempt to decrease FIO2 if SaO2 improves with paralysis
   - continue fentanyl/midazolam
   .
   # Sepsis / Fever:
   Afebrile.  Maintaining BP off pressors.  Sepsis initially due to
   multifocal PNA, as seen on CT chest. Wide differential given
   immunosuppression but influenza and other respiratory virus panel
   negative; AFB smear on BAL was negative, urine legionella negative.
   Culture from BAL with less than 1,000 colonies, Gram stain negative for
   PMN
s or organisms. BAL: prelim negative for CMV.  C diff [**11-17**]
   negative.  First glucan and galactomannan negative.
   - f/u ID recs
   - on meropenem/vanc (treat for 14-day course, day 1 = [**11-10**])
   - on voriconazole (day 1 = [**2114-11-19**])
   - Continue Bactrim at treatment dose
   - F/U pending blood cultures; acid fast, fungal, viral BAL cultures,
   repeat glucan, repeat galactomannan
   .
   # Anemia:
   Hct stable. No recurrence of GI bleeding.
   - monitor Hct
   - Active T+S
   - Transfuse for Hct < 21
   .
   # ARF: Cr above baseline but stable.
   - renally dose meds
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   - continue lasix drip to decrease LOS fluid balance, goal of UOP
   greater than 150cc per hour (b/c getting at least 100cc/hr IN)
   - consider adding metolozone if not diuresing well
   .
   # Elevated LFTs: Etiology unclear. [**Name2 (NI) 3234**] shows normal liver, biliary
   system except for gallbladder polyp.
   - trend LFTs
   .
   # ALL:
   On chronic immunosuppression s/p single cord blood transplantation.
   - Cont acyclovir ppx
   - Will not need to restart tacrolimus
   - on solumedrol
   - Appreciate BMT recs
   .
   # Hep B:
   - Cont lamivudine
   .
   #Constipation:
   Need to continue bowel regimen aggressively b/c of increased fentanyl w
   sedation now.
   - continue po narcan prn and standing docusate b/c still on fentanyl
   - lactulose, bisacodyl, senna, erythromycin PRN also
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Boost Glucose Control (Full) - [**2114-11-18**] 05:47 AM 48 mL/hour
   Glycemic Control:  Insulin sliding scale
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2114-11-9**] 11:00 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2114-11-10**] 02:00 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SQ Heparin
 restarting at 5000 units daily (held for 2 days in
   setting of elevated PTT), pneumoboots
   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP:  bundle
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments: Husband (cantonese speaking) and son (speaks
   english)
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: ICU

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 52-year-old female with ALL who has undergone chemo and single cord blood transplantation, complicated by CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis. She presents with pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: Hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS, requiring high FIO2 (100%) and mechanical ventilation with a trial of propofol, which was discontinued due to lack of improvement in synchrony. Cisatracurium was added, which improved oxygenation.
* Sepsis: Afebrile, with a diagnosis of multifocal PNA on CT chest. The patient is receiving meropenem and vancomycin for 14-day course, and voriconazole was started on day 1.
* Anemia: Hct stable, with no recurrence of GI bleeding.
* ARF: Cr above baseline but stable, with ongoing lasix drip to decrease fluid balance.
* Elevated LFTs: Etiology unclear, with ongoing trend.
* ALL: On chronic immunosuppression s/p single cord blood transplantation.
* Hep B: Cont lamivudine.
* Constipation: Need to continue bowel regimen aggressively due to increased fentanyl.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: Continued hypoxemia and respiratory failure may require further interventions, such as increasing PEEP, adjusting ventilation settings, or considering extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
* Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may worsen, leading to organ dysfunction or failure. Monitoring of vital signs, laboratory values, and clinical status is essential.
* ARF: The patient's ARF may progress, requiring further interventions, such as dialysis or hemofiltration.
* Elevated LFTs: The etiology of the elevated LFTs remains unclear, and ongoing monitoring is necessary to determine if the liver function improves or worsens.
* GVHD: The patient's GVHD may worsen, leading to further organ dysfunction or failure. Monitoring of vital signs, laboratory values, and clinical status is essential.
* Infections: The patient is at risk for further infections, particularly given her immunosuppressed state. Monitoring of vital signs, laboratory values, and clinical status is essential.

Recommendations for further management include:

* Continue mechanical ventilation with a trial of propofol to improve synchrony.
* Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely, with adjustments to ventilation settings as necessary.
* Continue antifungal and antibacterial therapy as prescribed.
* Monitor the patient's anemia and ARF, with adjustments to therapy as necessary.
* Trend the patient's LFTs to determine if the liver function improves or worsens.
* Monitor the patient's GVHD, with adjustments to therapy as necessary.
* Continue bowel regimen aggressively to manage constipation.
* Monitor the patient's constipation, with adjustments to therapy as necessary.
* Consider restarting tacrolimus, given the patient's history of GVHD.
* Continue lamivudine for Hep B prophylaxis.
* Consider adding metolozone to the patient's medication regimen if she is not diuresing well.

   Assessment and Plan
   52 yof ALL s/p cord blood transplant (>200 days) now with progressive
   hypoxemic respiratory failure and ARDS.
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE
 Some clinical improvement overnight.  Marked
   hypoxemia, but tolerating lower FiO2.   Attributed to ARDS (supported
   by measurements) and possible infection and possible cardiogenic
   pulmonary edema.  Unclear as to component of GVHD.  Continue with broad
   spectrum antibiotics
   (vancomycin/meropenem/voriconazole/mycafungin/Bactrim).  Adjust ETT.
   Continue mechanical ventilation, hope to decrease FiO2 to <60% if
   possible, and adjust PEEP as tolerated to improve oxygenation.  Monitor
   plerual pressures.   Monitor CXR.
   PULMONARY INFILTRATES
 diffuse, pleural effusions.  Attributble to
   ARDS, less likely infection (ex. VAP), but may in part related to net
   positive fluid balance.  Continue antibiotics, continue net diuresis.
   Consider diagnostic bronchoscopy, but may be high risk in context of
   marginal oxygenation and PEEP.
   HYPERNATREMIA
 improved with free water.  Monitor Na.
   SEPSIS
 resolved, remains off pressors.   Initially due to multifocal
   PNA, as seen on CT chest.
   ACUTE RENAL FAILURE
 attributed to ATN.  Resolving.  Continue monitor
   BUN, creatinine.  Hold lasix drip to allow reequilibration.
   ELEVATED LFTs
 Possible component of GVHD.  Currently stable.  Monitor
   LFTs.
   FLUIDS
 net positive.  Desire net negative daily fluid balance.
   ALL -- s/p cord blood transplantation.   BMTx team following.
   HEPATITIS B -- Continue lamivudine.
   ANEMIA
 Normocytic.  Hct stable.  Transfuse for Hct < 21
